{{notability|Biographies|date=November 2015}} '''Abu Hajal Muslim ibn Awsaja''' ({{lang-ar|ابوحَجَل مسلم بن عوسجه الأسدي}}) was a companion of Islamic Prophet [[Muhammad]]. He assisted [[Muslim ibn Aqeel]] in [[Kufa]]. Then he joined [[Husayn ibn Ali]] army with his family. He was killed in [[battle of Karbala]].{{cite book|author1=Syed Ghulam Abbas|author2=Mir Babbar Ali Anis|title=The Immortal Poetry & Mir Anis: With the Versified Translation of a Marsia of Mir Anis|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LeljAAAAMAAJ|year=1983|publisher=Majlis-e-Milli, Pakistan}} == Name and lineage == He is Muslim son of Awsaja son of Sa'd son of Tha'laba son of Dudan son of Asad son of Khuzayma al-Asadi. His [[Kunya (Arabic)|Kunya]] is Abu Hajal. He was a companion of [[Husayn ibn Ali]]. Muslim ibn Awsaja and [[Habib ibn Madhahir]] both were from the tribe of [[Banu Asad ibn Khuzaymah|Banu Asad]].{{cite book|last1=Samavi|first1=Muhammad|title=Absar al-Ein fi Ansar al-Husayn|publisher=al-Derasat al-Islamiyya|location=Qom|isbn=964-90575-7-9|pages=108–111|url=http://www.noorlib.ir/View/fa/Book/BookView/Image/1767/1/133}} == In Kufa == Mulim ibn Awsaja supported [[Husayn ibn Ali]]’s ambassador, [[Muslim ibn Aqeel]], in [[Kufa]] with weaponry and tried to take oath of allegiance for Husayn ibn Ali. The spy of [[Ubayd Allah ibn Ziyad]], Ma'qil, found the safe house of Muslim ibn Aqeel through Muslim ibn Awsaja. Consequently, [[Hani ibn Urwa]] who sheltered Muslim ibn Aqeel in his house was arrested. Then Muslim ibn Aqeel to organizing an army chose Muslim ibn Awsaja as commander of [[Banu Asad]] and [[Madh'hij]] and some other commanders. Soon after Hani ibn Urwa and Muslim ibn Aqeel were killed by Ubayd Allah ibn Ziyad, and Muslim ibn Awsaja hided in a safe house for a while. Afterward he joined Husayn ibn Ali army with his family in [[Karbala]].{{cite book|last1=Qomi|first1=Abbas|title=Nafs al-Mahmoom|publisher=al-Maktaba al-Heydariyya|location=Qom|url=http://www.noorlib.ir/View/fa/Book/BookView/Image/1984}} == In Karbala == === The Night before Ashura === At [[Day of Tasu'a|Tasu'a]] night, Husayn ibn Ali told his soldiers:
You are allowed to leave Karbala and your promises and oath of allegiance have served well so far, you are not obligated to stay for the battle.
Then, some companions proclaimed their allegiance and loyalty to Husayn ibn Ali over again. After the descendants of [[Banu Hashim]], Mulim ibn Awsaja was the first one who said:
Oh, [[Husayn ibn Ali|Abu Abd-Allah]]! We would never leave you alone. How it is possible to bring excuses to Allah? O, by Allah, never! We will never leave you alone; I will never give up; I will slay the enemies with my spear and sword until it drops on the ground; then I stone them. By Allah, I would never leave you alone until I fulfill my duties to Allah and defend the descendants of Prophet Muhammad. O, by Allah, if I am perished, I would reborn, and then if I am burnt and turned into ashes, I would reborn; and if it happens seventy times I would reborn and fight for you until I am martyred for you. I would never leave you as I know I will be perished once. Consequently, eternal prosperity and dignity would be mine.{{cite book|last1=ʻUmar Ibn Kathīr|first1=Ismāʻīl|title=al-Bidāyah wa-al-nihāyah|publisher=Dar al-Fekr|location=Beirut|page=177|url=http://www.noorlib.ir/View/fa/Book/BookView/Image/13958/1/172}}
==== His motto in the battle of Karbala ==== He repeatedly expressed this motto in the [[battle of Karbala]]:
If you desire to know me, I am brave as a lion; my lineage goes back to Banu Asad. If you treat me with tyranny, you are strayed from the right path, and you are guilty of ingratitude toward Allah.
It should be noted that [[Asad]] means lion. == Death == Muslim ibn Awsaja was the first one who was killed in the battle of Karbala before Amr ibn Qartah.{{cite book|title=Nafasul Mahmoom|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Wv3dBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA275|publisher=JAC Developer|pages=275–|id=GGKEY:RQAZ12CNGF5}} He was about 70 years old.{{cite book|author=Ibn El-Neil|title=The Truth About Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nlUq-sMt5ccC&pg=PA204|date=1 November 2008|publisher=Strategic Book Publishing|isbn=978-1-60693-259-9|pages=208}} == See also == * [[List of casualties in Husayn's army at the Battle of Karbala]] * [[Day of Ashura]] * [[Day of Tasu'a]] * [[Burayr ibn Khuzayr al-Hamadani]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:7th-century Muslims]] [[Category:Arabs]] [[Category:Muslim martyrs]]

{{Use Australian English|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{about|early camel drivers in Australian history|Australians of Afghan origin|Afghan Australians|other uses|Afghan (disambiguation)}} {{Islam in Australia}} [[Image:Afghan grave bourke.jpg|thumb|thumbnail|Grave of Afghan camel caravanner Zeriph Khan (1871-1903) at [[Bourke, New South Wales|Bourke]] Cemetery, New South Wales Australia]] [[File:Adelaide Mosque 1.jpg|thumb|The Adelaide Mosque (1888-89)
in Little Gilbert Street, [[Adelaide]]]] [[File:Adelaide Mosque 2.JPG|thumb|Adelaide Mosque historic plaque]] The "'''Afghans'''" or "'''Ghans'''" were [[camel train|camel caravanners]] who worked in [[Outback]] [[Australia]] from the 1860s to the 1930s. They included [[Pashtuns|Pashtun]], [[Punjabis|Punjabi]], [[Baloch people|Baloch]] and [[Sindhis|Sindhi]] men from the region between the southern [[Hindu Kush]] in [[Afghanistan]] and the [[Indus River]] in what is now [[Pakistan]],Westrip, J. & Holroyde, P. (2010): ''Colonial Cousins: a surprising history of connections between India and Australia.'' [[Wakefield Press (Australia)|Wakefield Press]]. {{ISBN|1862548412}}, p. 175. as well as others from [[Kashmir]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Egypt]], [[Persia]] and [[Turkey]].[http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/afghan-cameleers australia.gov.au > About Australia > Australian Stories > Afghan cameleers in Australia] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140815171331/http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/afghan-cameleers |date=15 August 2014 }} Accessed 8 May 2014. Besides providing vital support to exploration and settlement of the arid interior of the country, these cameleers played a major role in establishing [[Islam in Australia]], building the country's [[Marree Mosque|first mosque at Marree]] in South Australia. ==History== The first Afghan cameleers arrived in [[Melbourne]] in June 1860, when three men arrived with a shipment of 24 camels for the [[Burke and Wills expedition]]. Afghans without camels are reported to have reached Australia as early as 1838.[http://www.southaustralianhistory.com.au/afghans.htm Flinders Range Research - The Afghan Camelmen] Before the building of railways and the widespread adoption of motor vehicles, camels were the primary means of [[bulk transport]] in the Outback, where the climate was too harsh for horses and other beasts of burden. After their use was superseded by modern transport, some cameleers released their camels into the wild, and a large population of [[Australian feral camel|feral camels]] remains from this time. From 1850-1900, Afghani camel handlers played an important part in opening up Central Australia, helping in building of telegraph and railway lines. They also helped the growth of Muslims in Australia before 1850. ==Impact== Even though the Afghans' help was greatly appreciated they were also subject to discrimination because of their religion and appearance, and because of the competition they provided to European bullock teamsters. Many of those European competitors were also cameleers and in 1903 a European camel train proprietor of [[Wilcannia]] replaced all of his Afghan camel drivers with Europeans.''National Advocate'' newspaper, 17 April 1903, page 2. The passenger train which travels between [[Adelaide]] and [[Darwin, Northern Territory|Darwin]] is known as "[[The Ghan]]" (formerly ''[[The Afghan Express]]'') as a reference to the service the Afghans provided to the areas through which the train travels.[http://www.prr.org.au/cms/train-services-mainmenu-81/afghan-express-mainmenu-69 Afghan Express] The total number of Afghans to settle in Australia was approximately 3,000, with over 2,000 arriving between 1870 and 1900. ===Establishment of mosques=== At [[Marree]], an important junction of the camel trade, the Afghan cameleers built the earliest mosque in Australia in 1861, but this subsequently fell into disuse and was demolished. Over time as some members of the Afghan community prospered through trade and camel breeding, they contributed towards the building of the oldest permanent mosque in Australia, in Adelaide in 1888–89,[http://www.weekendnotes.com/adelaide-city-afghan-mosque/ Weekend Notes > Adelaide City Afghan Mosque] Accessed 8 May 2014. as well as the Perth mosque, which dates from 1905.{{sfn|Westrip & Holroyde|p. 193}} ==Notable people== * [[Dervish Bejah]] * [[Dost Mahomet]] * [[Ben Barba]] ==See also== *[[Afghan Australian]] * [[Ahmadiyya in Australia]] *[[Indian Australians]] *[[Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin ]] *[[Pashtun diaspora]] *[[Demography of Afghanistan]] *[[Battle of Broken Hill]] ==References== *{{cite book |author=Stevens, Christine |year=2003 |origyear=1989 |title=Tin Mosques and Ghan Towns: A History of Afghan Camel Drivers in Australia |isbn=0-9581760-0-0}} ==External links== * [http://www.ntl.nt.gov.au/__data/assets/pdf_file/0017/100853/Camel_Guide.pdf Bibliography on Camels and Cameleers at the Northern Territory Library.] * [http://www.southaustralianhistory.com.au/afghans.htm Flinders Ranges Research > ''The Afghan Camelmen''] Accessed 8 May 2014. * [http://www.abc.net.au/gnt/history/Transcripts/s1231969.htm ABC TV > George Negus Tonight > ''Afghan Cameleers''] Broadcast transcript, 1 November 2004. Accessed 8 May 2014. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080720061848/http://www.bushmag.com.au/History/Pioneering_Afghans.htm ''Pioneering Afghans'' from Bushmag.] [[Category:Asian Australian]] [[Category:Islam in Australia]] [[Category:Pakistani diaspora in Australia]] [[Category:Exploration of Australia]] [[Category:Transport in Australia]] [[Category:Afghan diaspora]] [[Category:Camel drivers]] [[Category:Social history of Australia]]

[[File:Bicycle courier 552.JPG|thumb|Bicycle courier, [[London]], [[UK]], riding a fixed gear bicycle with [[spoke cards]]]] [[File:Courier transferring urgent mail onto a high-speed train.JPG|thumb|Bicycle courier transferring urgent mail onto a high-speed train in Geneva, Switzerland]]
'''Bicycle messengers''' (also known as '''bike''' or '''cycle couriers''') are people who work for [[courier]] companies (also known as messenger companies) carrying and delivering items by [[bicycle]]. Bicycle messengers are most often found in the [[central business district]]s of metropolitan areas. Courier companies use bike messengers because bicycle travel is less subject to unexpected holdups in city [[Traffic congestion|traffic jams]], and is not deterred by parking limitations, fees or fines in high density development that can hinder or prevent delivery by motor vehicle, thereby offering a predictable delivery time.
==History== [[File:BikeBoys.jpg|thumb|Bicycle messenger boys, [[Salt Lake City]], 1912]]
Almost immediately after the development of the pedal-driven [[velocipede]] in the 1860s, people began to use the bicycle for delivery purposes. [[David V. Herlihy]]'s 2004 book on the early history of the bicycle contains several references to bicycle messengers working during the late 19th century, including a description of couriers employed by the Paris stock exchange in the 1870s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Herlihy |first=David V. |authorlink=David V. Herlihy |title=Bicycle: the History |publisher=Yale University Press |year=2004 |page=177 |url= http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/book.asp?isbn=9780300104189 |isbn=0-300-10418-9}}</ref> During the [[bicycle boom]] of the 1890s in the United States, [[Western Union]] employed a number of bicycle [[telegraph boy]]s in [[New York City]], [[San Francisco]], and other large population centers.
One of the earliest recorded post-war American bicycle courier companies was founded by Carl Sparks, in [[San Francisco]], in 1945. According to the San Francisco Bicycle Messenger Association, "Sparkie's went on to become Aero, which was bought out in 1998 [and] later absorbed into CitySprint."<ref>{{cite web|title=A History of Bike Messengering in San Francisco |publisher=San Francisco Bicycle Messenger Association |date=September 1996 |url= http://www.ahalenia.com/sfbma/history.html |accessdate=2007-10-01}}</ref> By the late 1970s, there were well-established companies offering bicycle messenger services in many major cities in the U.S.
In Europe, the bicycle had fallen out of favour as a means of delivery in the third quarter of the 20th century. It was not until 1983 that bicycle messengers made their reappearance in Europe. London's "On Yer Bike" and "Pedal-Pushers" were pioneers of pedal over petrol, and the rest of the city's courier companies followed suit. By the late 1980s, cycle couriers were a common sight in central London and a British manufacturer named a range of mountain-bikes for them, the Muddy Fox 'Courier'.<ref>{{cite web |title=Value Judgement |publisher=The Washing Machine Post |date=1998-04-11 |url=http://www.ileach.co.uk/post/archive/archivepost12.html |quote=When I entered the grand world of cycling in a proper way instead of playing on a terrible ten speed racer, i bought a Muddy Fox Courier for £300 [sic] |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070821210443/http://www.ileach.co.uk/post/archive/archivepost12.html |archivedate=21 August 2007 |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> Entrepreneurs in continental Europe, some inspired by seeing couriers in the U.S. or in London, began to offer bicycle courier services in the late 1980s, and by 1993 there were sufficiently large numbers of bicycle couriers in Northern Europe and North America that over 400 attended the inaugural Cycle Messenger Championships in Berlin, Germany.<ref>{{cite web |title=A Short history of the Cycle Messenger World Championships |publisher=International Federation of Bicycle Messengers and Associations |date=October 1998 |url=http://www.messengers.org/ifbma/history.html |quote=500 messengers showed up, raced, drank beer, smoked and hung out. The Cycle Messenger World Championships had been born. |accessdate=2007-10-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071014041311/http://messengers.org/ifbma/history.html |archivedate=2007-10-14 |df= }}</ref> Bicycle messengers have not become common in southern Europe, the heartland of world competitive cycling. There are very few bicycle couriers in Portugal, France, Spain, or Italy. Outside Europe and North America, there are now large bicycle messenger services in Japan, and also in [[New Zealand]] and [[Australia]]. More recently, several companies started offering bike messenger services in Central and South America, specifically in México City, México; San José, Costa Rica; Bogotá, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; Rio de Janeiro and São Paulo, Brazil.
==Demand for courier services== Messengers carry a huge variety of items, from things that could not be sent by digital means (corporate gifts, original artwork, clothes for photo-shoots, original signed documents) to mundane items that could easily be emailed, albeit without the air of importance attached to an express courier delivery. Messengers deliver digital content on [[optical media]] or [[Hard disk drive|hard disks]] because, despite high speed broadband connections, companies find it easier to send a disc than to work out how to transmit larger amounts of data than an email account can handle.<ref>{{cite web |title=Piracy And Securing The Digital Media Supply Chain |url=http://publications.mediapost.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=Articles.showArticleHomePage&art_aid=73253 |date=2007-12-31 |publisher=Video Insider |accessdate=2008-01-05 }}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Sneakernet Redux: Walk Your Data |url= https://www.wired.com/news/culture/0,1284,54739,00.html |date=2002-08-26 |publisher=Wired Magazine |accessdate=2007-09-19}}</ref> Legal documents, various financial instruments and sensitive information are routinely sent by courier, reflecting a distrust of digital cryptography.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.clir.org/pubs/reports/pub92/lynch.html |first=Clifford |last=Lynch |title=Authenticity and Integrity in the Digital Environment |date=May 2000 |publisher=Council on Library and Information Resources |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref>
Commentators have claimed that technological innovation will significantly reduce the demand for same-day parcel delivery,<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/g2/story/0,,2118772,00.html |publisher=Guardian Media |first=Matt |last=Seaton |title=Two Wheels column |date=2007-07-05 |location=London |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831092911/http://www.guardian.co.uk/g2/story/0%2C%2C2118772%2C00.html |archivedate=31 August 2007 |accessdate=2007-09-17 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/19/world/fax-displacing-manhattan-bike-couriers.html |date=1990-03-19 |title=Fax Displacing Manhattan Bike Couriers |publisher=The New York Times |first=Robert |last=Tomasson |accessdate=2007-09-17}}</ref> predicting that the [[fax machine]], and then the [[internet]], would render the messenger business obsolete. There is still a demand for fast courier services<ref>{{cite web|date=7 July 2006 |publisher=The Economist |title=Soft Pedal |url= http://twocitiestwowheels.blogspot.com/2006/07/economist-and-bike-messengers.html |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> but there is certainly some truth in the predictions. Reliable data specifically relating to bicycle messenger occupational statistics is hard to find: the [[United States Department of Labor|U.S. Department of Labor]] [[statistics]] does not track bicycle messengers specifically, and does not include "independent contractors" in statistics referenced for this industry occupation,<ref>{{cite web | title=US Department of Labor | publisher=Bureau of Labor Statistics |url= http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes435021.htm |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090106010254/http://www.bls.gov/oes/current/oes435021.htm |archivedate=6 January 2009 |accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> but reports indicate the business is shrinking.
The gradual acceptance of electronic filing by U.S. courts has had a negative effect on the market. In San Francisco, bike messengers report a smaller work force coupled with decreased earnings.<ref>{{cite news | first=Kathleen | last=Pender | title=Bicycle messengers are pedaling uphill against the Internet | publisher=San Francisco Chronicle | url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/07/17/BUGOSR1ET51.DTL | accessdate=2009-01-09 | date=2007-07-18}}</ref> In New York alone, the number of messengers dropped by approximately 1,000 between 1998 and 2008.<ref>{{cite news | title=Internet Endangers Big-City Tradition: The Bike Messenger | url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2008/07/bikemessengers |date=2008-07-25 | publisher=Wired Magazine | accessdate=2008-07-25| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080726225922/http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2008/07/bikemessengers| archivedate= 26 July 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Working conditions== [[File:Julia Obear, messenger girl at the National Women's (i.e. Woman's) Party headquarters LCCN92522519 (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Bicycle messenger at the headquarters of the [[National Woman's Party]], 1922]] The conditions of employment of bicycle messengers vary from country to country, city to city and even company to company. Contracts governing the relationship between individual courier and company are subject as much to customary practice, as local ordinance. In some places messengers are [[independent contractor]]s paid on [[Commission (remuneration)|commission]] and do not receive benefits such as health insurance. In other places they will be regular [[employee]]s of the courier company enjoying all the benefits thereof.
The employment status of the bicycle messengers of one of the UK's biggest same-day courier services, CitySprint, was challenged by the [[GMB (trade union)|GMB]] [[trade union]] in December 2007. The challenge arose after the firm terminated the contract of one of its riders. The GMB sought to establish that more than 1,500 CitySprint operatives currently classified as self-employed sub-contractors should be re-classified as employees.<ref>{{cite news |author= Nick Mathiason |title= Christmas sacking starts fight for rights of dispatched courier |url= https://www.theguardian.com/business/2007/dec/23/2 |publisher= Guardian Media |location= London, UK |date= 2007-12-23 |accessdate=2007-12-24 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080106124055/http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2007/dec/23/2| archivedate= 6 January 2008 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The job is poorly paid relative to the risk and effort required. In 2002, a [[Harvard Medical School]] study of injury rates among [[Boston]] bicycle messengers determined that the rate of injury requiring time off work among the sample group was more than thirteen times the U.S. average, and more than three times higher than the next highest group, workers in the meat-packing industry.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Dennerlein, Meeker | title=Occupational Injuries Among Boston Bicycle Messengers | version= | publisher=Harvard School of Public Health |date=2002-02-06 | url=http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/ergonomics/bike/index.html | accessdate=2007-09-17}}</ref> Bike messengers have been killed while working in the United States.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.iww.org/en/node/3578 |title= Tragedy strikes the CCU |accessdate= 2009-01-27 |author= Greg Ehrendreich |date=2007-08-15 |publisher= www.iww.org |quote= "a bicycle messenger in the Chicago Couriers Union (IU 540), was killed on the job yesterday." }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/08/11/nyregion/11mbrfs-001.html?sq=New+York%3A+Manhattan%3A+Bike+Messenger+Killed&scp=2&st=cse |title= Manhattan: Bike Messenger Killed |accessdate= 2007-09-23 |author= Emily Vasquez |date=2006-08-11 |publisher= New York Times |quote= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ahalenia.com/memorial/mcbride.html |title= Thomas McBride |accessdate= 2007-09-23 |year=1999 |publisher= Messenger Memorial |quote= d. 26.April.1999 murdered by Carnell Fitzpatrick, driver of a Chevy Tahoe. }}</ref> Eight bicycle messengers are known to have been killed while working in [[London]] between 1989 and 2003.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.movingtargetzine.com/memorial |title=Dedication |accessdate=2007-09-23 |author='Buffalo' Bill Chidley |date=2005-10-13 |year= |month= |publisher=Moving Target |quote=London Bicycle Messengers killed while working: Joe Cooper, Calvin Simpson, Paul Ellis, Edward Newstead, Mark Francis, Reidar "Danny" Farr, Sebastian Lukomski | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070926025905/http://www.movingtargetzine.com/memorial| archivedate= 26 September 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Because payment is made at [[piece rate]]s, it is hard to get reliable figures for messenger income. A study published in 2006 stated that the average daily wage of London bicycle messengers was £65 a day, and that of bicycle messenger in Cardiff was £45.<ref>{{cite journal | last= Fincham | first= Ben |year= 2007 |title= ‘Generally speaking people are in it for the cycling and the beer’: Bicycle couriers, subculture and enjoyment |journal= The Sociological Review|volume= 55|issue= 2|page= 192 |doi= 10.1111/j.1467-954X.2007.00701.x }}</ref> The UK legal minimum wage at that time was £5.52 an hour.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.dti.gov.uk/employment/pay/national-minimum-wage/index.html| title= National Minimum Wage| accessdate= 2007-12-30| date= 2005-10-13| publisher= UK Department for Business, Enterprise & Regulatory Reform| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080101051207/http://www.dti.gov.uk/employment/pay/national-minimum-wage/index.html| archivedate= 1 January 2008| deadurl= yes| df= }}</ref>
==Licensing== In most cities, there are no legal requirements beyond those applying to all cyclists. Some jurisdictions, though, require the licensing of courier bicycles. In [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]] for example, metal license plates must be fixed to bicycles used for courier work.<ref>{{cite web | title=Calgary City Business License information FAQ | publisher=City of Calgary | url=http://www.calgary.ca/portal/server.pt/gateway/PTARGS_0_0_104_0_0_35/http%3B/content.calgary.ca/CCA/City+Hall/Business+Units/Development+and+Building+Approvals+and+Land+Use+Planning+and+Policy/Business+Licences/Business+Licence+FAQs.htm#Question4 | accessdate=2009-01-18 }}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] additionally requires bicycle messengers to complete a test in order to obtain a license, and to carry an identification card.<ref>{{cite web | title=City of Vancouver Community Services/Licenses and Inspections | publisher=City of Vancouver | url=http://vancouver.ca/commsvcs/LICANDINSP/licences/pdf/bikecourierguide.pdf | accessdate=2010-10-08}}</ref>
==Equipment== The most essential piece of equipment for a bicycle messenger is a [[bicycle]]. Some large cities that employ significant numbers of bike messengers (e.g., New York City) have relatively flat terrain, and are especially conducive to the performance properties of fixed gear bicycles.
Because bicycle thefts are prevalent in many cities,<ref>{{cite news | title=Bicycles stolen every 71 seconds | publisher=BBC News |date=2007-04-27 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/6596559.stm | accessdate=2007-09-24 | quote=The hotspots for [bicycle] thefts are central London }}</ref> a lock to secure the bike during deliveries is essential. [[U-lock]]s are also popular. Messengers typically carry basic tools, weather-proof clothing and a street map.<ref>{{cite web | first='Buffalo' Bill | last=Chidley | title=How to be a messenger and not get stitched up, nicked or run over | publisher=London Bicycle Messenger Association | url=http://www.londonmessengers.org/FAQ | accessdate=2010-12-29 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080629084442/http://www.londonmessengers.org/FAQ | archivedate=2008-06-29|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
The majority of messengers use a bag to carry deliveries and personal effects. Bags with a single strap that wraps diagonally across the chest (popularly known as [[messenger bag]]) are popular because they can be swung around the messenger's body to allow access without removing the bag. Clasps which can be adjusted with one hand (ideal for riding), clips, pockets and webbing loops on the strap for holding a [[cell phone]] or [[two-way radio]] and other equipment also feature on purpose-built messenger bags. Bags generally have large capacities (up to 50 liters or 3,000 cubic inches). Baskets and racks mounted on the bike are also used, and at least one messenger service (in [[New York City]]) equips its riders with specialized three-wheel cycles (sometimes known as [[cargo bike|cargo-trikes]]), with a large trunk in the rear. Many bicycle messengers also wear helmets and mount lights and fenders (mud guards) to their bicycles.
==Communications== Messengers communicate and are dispatched to assignments via hand-held communication devices including [[two-way radio]]s, [[cell phone]]s, and [[personal digital assistant]]s. Many of the larger messenger services equip their riders with [[GPS tracking]] devices,<ref>{{cite web | first='Buffalo' Bill | last=Chidley | title=The End of Bicycle Messengering As We Know It? | publisher=Moving Target | url=http://www.movingtargetzine.com/article/the-beginning-of-the-end-of-bicycle-messengering-as-we-know-it | accessdate=2007-09-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070814002904/http://www.movingtargetzine.com/article/the-beginning-of-the-end-of-bicycle-messengering-as-we-know-it| archivedate= 14 August 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> for ease of location.
==Messenger culture and influence==
===Media=== [[File:US bike messenger stamp 1902.jpg|thumb|1902 US postal stamp depicting a bicycle messenger]] Messengers have been used in fiction media as symbols of urban living, and have been the subject of novels,<ref>{{cite book | last=Gibson | first=William | title=[[Virtual Light]] | publisher=[[Viking Press]] |date=1994-10-06 | location=London | isbn=978-0-14-015772-7 }}</ref> memoirs,<ref>{{cite book | last=Reilly | first=Rebecca | title=Nerves of Steel: Bike Messengers in the United States | publisher=Spoke and Word |date=August 2000 | location=New York | isbn=978-0-9703426-0-7 }}</ref> feature films,<ref>[[Quicksilver (film)|Quicksilver, 1986 film about a stock broker who becomes a NYC messenger]]</ref> television series,<ref>{{cite web | title=Streetwise, a UK children's TV series about a cycle courier company | url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0168380/ | accessdate=2007-09-18}}</ref> comic-books,<ref>{{Comic book reference | writer= Jones, Jay | penciller=Jones, Jay | title=Messenger 29 | volume=1 | issue=1 |date=September 1989 | publisher= September Press }}</ref> and sociological studies.<ref>{{cite journal | last= Fincham | first= Ben |year= 2007 |title= ‘Generally speaking people are in it for the cycling and the beer’: Bicycle couriers, subculture and enjoyment |journal= The Sociological Review|volume= 55|issue= 2|pages= 189–202 |doi= 10.1111/j.1467-954X.2007.00701.x }}</ref> Mexican artist [[José Guadalupe Posada]] created a popular icon of a marijuana-smoking bicycle courier [[everyman]] in his 19th-century engravings.
The 1986 film ''[[Quicksilver (film)|Quicksilver]]'' featuring a bicycle messenger, is an early expression of the mythology of the messenger as daredevil stunt rider.<ref>{{cite web|last=Guerrero |first=Jeff |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/pg/07252/815585-109.stm |title=The Next Page: The Limberness of the Fixed Gear Mind |publisher=Post-gazette.com |date=2007-09-09 |accessdate=2014-08-16}}</ref> Star [[Kevin Bacon]] rides a racing bike, a fixed gear bike and a [[Artistic cycling|trick bike]] with 1:1 gear ratio and zero-rake forks, to perform the stunts in the film. The 2000–2002 television series ''[[Dark Angel (2000 TV series)|Dark Angel]]'' had the main character Max Guevara, played by [[Jessica Alba]], as a bicycle messenger at a courier service named Jam Pony. The show took place in a [[post-apocalyptic]] [[Seattle]] where motorized transportation was costly and therefore couriers were more prevalent and bicycle messengers were seen as a prominent position. The 2012 film ''[[Premium Rush]]'', starring [[Joseph Gordon-Levitt]], is also set in the world of bike messengers. In the TV show ''[[Suits (U.S. TV series)|Suits]]'', [[Patrick J. Adams]] often has flashback scenes to previous job as a bike messenger. The main character of the game [[inFAMOUS]] is also a bike messenger who possesses amazing skills in parkour and urban-exploration.
News media have made portrayals of messengers ranging from innocuous urban libertines to reckless, cliquish [[Nihilism|nihilists]]. The latter portrayal is often sparked by local incidents involving bike messengers in collisions with other road-users or run-ins with authority figures.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.governing.com/archive/1999/jun/bike.txt | work=[[Governing (magazine)|Governing]] | title=Messenger mayhem | first=Charles | last=Mahtesian | accessdate=2009-01-13 }} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> These incidents also occasionally lead to proposals for, and dispute over, new ordinances and regulations on messengers and messengering.<ref>{{cite news | title=Messengers don't like Council's signals | work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | url=http://www.post-gazette.com/regionstate/19990908messenger1.asp | accessdate=2007-09-19 |date=1999-09-08 | first=Timothy | last=McNulty}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mass.gov/legis/laws/seslaw98/sl980302.htm | title=An Ordinance Concerning The Registration Of Commercial Bicycle Services And The Licensing Of Commercial Messengers | publisher=Government of Massachusetts | accessdate=2009-01-18}}</ref>
===Fashion=== The influence of bicycle messengers can be seen in urban fashion, most notably the popularity of single-strap messenger bags, which are a common accessory among people who do not ride a bicycle regularly. The rise in popularity of [[fixed-gear]] bicycles in the mid-2000s, complete with affectations such as [[spoke card]]s (gathered from "[[Alleycat races|alleycats]]" typically), is attributed to bicycle messengers.<ref>{{cite news | first=Singel | last=Ryan | work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] | title=Fixed-Gear Bikes an Urban Fixture | url=https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2005/04/67149 | accessdate=2009-01-18 | date=2005-04-07| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090123222218/http://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2005/04/67149| archivedate= 23 January 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Events=== Since 1993, [[Cycle Messenger World Championships]], CMWCs, have taken place at national, continental and world levels.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.messengers.org/events/ | title=CYCLE MESSENGER WORLD CHAMPIONSHIPS Event Listings | author=IFBMA | publisher=IFBMA | accessdate=2009-01-27 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223112635/http://www.messengers.org/events/ | archivedate=2008-12-23 | df= }}</ref> These events are held as much for fun and messenger networking as for competition. Bicycle messengers also take part in formal cycle competitions at all levels, and in all disciplines. [[Nelson Vails]], silver medalist on the velodrome in the 1984 Olympics, worked as a bicycle messenger in [[New York City]] in the early 1980s. Ivonne Kraft, who competed in the [[Cycling at the 2004 Summer Olympics – Women's cross-country|2004 Olympic cross country mountain bike race]], is a multiple former Cycle Messenger World Champion, and worked as a bicycle messenger in Germany for a number of years.
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Cycle Messenger World Championships]] *[[Alleycat races]] *[[Bicycle culture]] *[[Courier]] *[[Telegraph boy]] *''[[Double Rush]]'' (sitcom) *[[Freight bicycle]] *[[Outline of cycling]] *[[Package delivery]] *''[[Premium Rush]]'' (movie) *''[[Triple Rush]]'' (reality TV) {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|2}}

'''Charles Spencer Storms,''' known as '''Charlie Storms''' (1823-1881) was a professional [[gunfighter]] and [[gambler]] of the [[Old West]], who is best known for having been killed in a gunfight with [[Luke Short]] in [[Tombstone, Arizona|Tombstone]], [[Arizona]].
== Early life ==
Charlie Storms was born in the state of [[New York (state)|New York]], as is shown by public records.<ref>1870 Federal Census for the First Precinct of the 7th Ward of the city of [[San Francisco]] (70 Minna street), at page 7, line 5, lists Charles Storms, aged 43, occupation gambler, as having been born in England; however, surviving voting lists for the period list him as Charles Spencer (or Spinner) Storms, born New York. Ancestry.com</ref> Storms was reported by the ''Tombstone Epitaph'' to have been in [[California]] during the [[California Gold Rush|Gold Rush]] of 1849,<ref name="weekly">{{cite news|date=February 27, 1881 |url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015133/1881-02-27/ed-1/seq-3/#date1=02%2F25%2F1881&index=3&date2=02%2F31%2F1887&searchType=advanced&language=&sequence=0&words=Luke+Short&proxdistance=5&state=Arizona&rows=20&ortext=&proxtext=Luke+Short&phrasetext=&andtext=&dateFilterType=range&page=1 |publisher=Arizona Weekly Citizen | page= 3 |title=A Tombstone dispatch}}</ref> which is corroborated by an entry in the 1852 California state census for the city of [[Sacramento]], that lists twenty-nine year old "Chas. S. Storms," a laborer born in New York who had last lived in Mexico.<ref>California State Library; Sacramento, California; 1852 California State Census; Roll #: 3; Repository Collection #: C144:3; Page: 109; Line: 35. ancestry.com</ref>
== Gambler and gunfighter ==
He had a reputation as being a skilled gunman during the 1870s and afterward, and traveled to many towns throughout the Old West as a gambler.<ref name=legends/> He drifted from place to place, including [[Deer Lodge, Montana|Deer Lodge]],<ref>1870 Federal census for Deer Lodge, Deer Lodge County, Montana Territory, p. 15, line 33</ref> [[Virginia City, Nevada|Virginia City]], [[Leadville, Colorado|Leadville]], [[Dodge City, Kansas]], [[Deadwood, South Dakota|Deadwood]], during which time he was involved in at least three shooting incidents. When [[Wild Bill Hickok]] was murdered by [[Jack McCall]] in [[Deadwood, South Dakota]], Storms was reportedly in town at the same time, and it was rumored that he stole one of Hickok's pistols as a souvenir, although this was never proven.<ref name=legends/>
He left [[El Paso, Texas]] and arrived in Tombstone in 1881. He was a well-known gambler and frequented [[Western saloon|saloon]]s in town.<ref name=legends>[http://www.legendsofamerica.com/we-gunfighterlist-s.html Charlie Storms]</ref>
== Fatal argument ==
On February 25, 1881, Storms had been drinking all night and made several rude remarks to [[faro (card game)|Faro]] dealer [[Luke Short]] in the Oriental Saloon. Storms had successfully defended himself several times with his pistol. He had inaccurately sized Short up as someone who, according to [[Bat Masterson]], he could "slap in the face without expecting a return." Masterson knew both men.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ostrand|first1=Maggie Van|title=Luke Short, The Undertakers' Friend|url=http://www.texasescapes.com/MaggieVanOstrand/Luke-Short-The-Undertakers-Friend.htm|accessdate=26 March 2015|date=December 20, 2007}}</ref><ref name=dearment>{{cite book|last1=DeArment|first1=Robert K.|title=Bat Masterson, the Man and the Legend|date=1989|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|location=Norman, Oklahoma|isbn=9780806170732|edition=First}}<!--|accessdate=26 March 2015--></ref>
{{quote|Charlie Storms was one of the best-known gamblers in the entire West and had, on several occasions, successfully defended himself in pistol fights with Western 'gunfighters...
Charlie Storms and I were very close friends, as much as Short and I were, and for that reason I did not care to see him get into what I knew would be a very serious difficulty. Storms did not know Short and, like the bad man in Leadville, had sized him up as an insignificant-looking fellow, whom he could slap in the face without expecting a return. Both were about to pull their pistols when I jumped between them and grabbed Storms, at the same time requesting Luke not to shoot, a request I knew he would respect if it was possible without endangering his own life too much. I had no trouble in getting Storms out of the house, as he knew me to be his friend. When Storms and I reached the street, I advised him to go to his room and take a sleep, for I then learned for the first time that he had been up all night, and had been quarreling with other persons...
I was just explaining to Luke that Storms was a very decent sort of man when, lo and behold! There he stood before us, without saying a word, at the same time pulling his pistol. Luke stuck the muzzle of his pistol against Storm's heart and pulled the trigger. The bullet tore the heart asunder and, as he was falling, Luke shot him again. Storms was dead when he hit the ground.}}
Short shot Storms in the chest twice at point-blank range, setting his shirt on fire.<ref name=drwin>{{cite book|last=Erwin|first=Richard E.|title=The Truth about Wyatt Earp|year=1993|publisher=O.K. Press|location=Carpinteria, CA|isbn=9780963393029|edition=2nd}}</ref> Short reportedly told Bat Masterson, "You sure pick some of the damnedest friends, Bat".<ref name=legends/>
Tombstone physician [[George E. Goodfellow]] was only a few feet from Storms when he was killed. "In the spring of 1881 I was a few feet distant from a couple of individuals <nowiki>[</nowiki>Luke Short and Charlie Storms<nowiki>]</nowiki> who were quarreling. They began shooting. The first shot took effect, as was afterward ascertained, in the left breast of one of them, who, after being shot, and while staggering back some 12 feet, cocked and fired his pistol twice, his second shot going into the air, for by that time he was on his back."<ref name=packer>{{cite web |url=http://www.americanheritage.com/content/%E2%80%9Cit-don%E2%80%99t-hurt-much-ma%E2%80%99am%E2%80%9C |first=James |last=Packer| title=It Don’t Hurt Much, Ma’am|publisher=American Heritage|accessdate=2013-03-17}}</ref> He found two thicknesses of silk wrapped around the bullet and two tears where it had struck the vertebral column.<ref name=oldwest>{{cite web|title=Dr. George Goodfellow |url=http://societyoftheoldwest.ning.com/forum/topics/dr-george-goodfellow |accessdate=8 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220090137/http://societyoftheoldwest.ning.com/forum/topics/dr-george-goodfellow |archivedate=20 December 2014 |df= }}</ref>
Examining Storms afterward, Goodfellow found that he had been shot in the heart, but was surprised to see "not a drop of blood" exiting the wound. He discovered that the bullet had ripped through the man's clothes and into a folded [[silk]] handkerchief in his breast pocket. He extracted the intact bullet from the wound with the silk wrapped around it.<ref name=prescott>{{cite news |first=Josh |last=Edwards |title=George Goodfellow's Medical Treatment of Stomach Wounds Became Legendary |publisher=The Prescott Courier |date=May 2, 1980|pages=3–5 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=886&dat=19800502&id=jH8vAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vkwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4536,249915}}</ref> As a result of what he learned, Goodfellow began experimenting with the first designs for [[bulletproof|bullet-resistant]] clothing made of multiple layers of silk.<ref name=hollington>{{cite web |last=Hollington |first=Kris |title=Staying Alive |url=http://www.assassinology.org/id20.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503151128/http://www.assassinology.org/id20.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 May 2007 |accessdate=4 March 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Short was arrested by Tombstone city Marshal [[Ben Sippy]] for killing Storms. During the preliminary hearing, Masterson testified that Short acted in [[self defense]] and Short was released.<ref name=prescott/> The ''Arizona Weekly'' reported that Storms was around 60 years old and that he was survived by a widow in San Francisco.<ref name="weekly"/> The 1870 Census returns lists a Mrs. Mary Storms, aged 40, born at sea, residing in the same San Francisco household with Charles Storms, along with two brothers Henry and George Goodman, aged 24 and 16 respectively, who may have been her sons from an earlier marriage.<ref>1900 Federal Census for the 35th Assembly District, City and County of San Francisco Enumeration District 120, Sheet 6-B, Line 55, lists her as being born October 1820 in England, had emigrated to the United States in 1822, and that she was the mother of two children who were both deceased.</ref> The [[San Francisco Call]] for November 26, 1903, at page 15 lists the death notice of "Mrs. Mary Storms," aged eighty four, who died on November 24 at the University Mound Ladies Home, an assisted care living facility for elderly women.<ref>(San Francisco) ''Call,'' vol. 94, no. 179, November 26, 1903, page 15</ref>
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
