{{BLP sources|date=September 2016}}
{{Infobox person | name = May Xue | native_name = 薛梅 | native_name_lang = Chinese | image = May Xue at the 2012 China Recruiting Show (cropped).jpg | caption = Xue in 2012 | birth_name = Mei Xue | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1973|07|05|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Xian]], [[China]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[China|Chinese]] | other_names = | occupation = Museum CEO | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''May Xue '''(born July 5, 1973) was the [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of the [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art]] in Beijing, China from 2011 to 2017. Prior to becoming [[Chief executive officer|CEO]], Xue was the [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art|UCCA]] Store retail director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MjM5NDY1MzIxNw==&mid=400449558&idx=2&sn=dcf7d7bd316d991adc6c9ff887fd4ce9&scene=1&srcid=0902QLxuCfZ0HNlPnB3vuVHG#wechat_redirect|title=Mission of the business strategy - Interview Ullens CEO Xue Mei|last=|first=|date=2015-11-08|website=|publisher=New Vision|access-date=}}</ref> In 2015, Xue was named one of the ''7'' ''Women in Contemporary Chinese Art You Need to Know'' by [[Artnet|ArtNet News]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/7-women-in-contemporary-chinese-art-you-need-to-know-280297|title=7 Women in Contemporary Chinese Art - artnet News|date=2015-03-23|language=en-US|access-date=2016-09-01}}</ref>
== Biography == Xue was born in [[Xi'an|Xian]], [[China]]. In 1985, at the age of 15, Xue moved to [[Shandong|Shangdong]] where she would finish her schooling all the way through university where she would earn a bachelor's degree in [[Hotel management|Hotel Management]] at [[Shandong University|Shangdong University]].
In 1994, Xue was introduced to an opportunity in [[Beijing]], [[China]], to work as an assistant for Pittler Group China's chief representative. Xue quickly built a good reputation within the company and was sent to the [[Goethe-Institut|Goethe Institut]] in [[Beijing]] to study [[German language|German]]. After completing two semesters at the [[Goethe-Institut|Goethe Institut]], she continued to work for Pittler Group China.
In 1998, Xue joined CapitalClub China <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mp.weixin.qq.com/s?__biz=MjM5MTY3NzkwMQ==&mid=204971103&idx=3&sn=9cd5b719b3ebd476e1d89a717c8bd1a6&scene=1&srcid=09021yhplARZewMp6pkG4qEs#wechat_redirect|title=Comfort interview with UCCA CEO May Xue|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Comfort Magazine|access-date=}}</ref> where she was hired as a membership officer. It only took Xue six months to be promoted to membership manager for [[China]]. Two years after her first promotion, Xue was once again promoted; this time to Capital Club's director of China. In 2002, Xue was awarded a chance to travel to any city in the world through Capital Club and chose [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. The director of [[ClubCorp]] (Capital Club's parent company) in [[Los Angeles]] immediately offered Xue a position. Xue spent three years working as a private events manager for City Club on Bunker Hill in [[Los Angeles]] before moving back to [[China]] in 2005.
Xue continued to work at Capital Club in [[Beijing]], this time as a [[Marketing Director|marketing director]], until late 2005 where she took on a position in [[Chengdu]], [[China]], at the China Club (private business club) as a [[general manager]].
In 2006, Xue was hired by [[Cartier (jeweler)|Cartier]] to become the area [[Retail management|retail manager]] of [[North China]]. Xue spent one-year at Cartier before starting her own [[public relations]] company called Imperial Connect. The company last just under two years (2007-2009). During those two years, Imperial Connect partnered with [[Jet Set Sports]] to become a VIP host for the [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Olympics]] where Xue held the role of [[Event management|event manager]]. Imperial Connect also worked with [[Hainan Airlines]] to host the inaugural [[China]] to [[Seattle]] flight event. Most of Imperial Connect's clients were in the art industry. The Bruce Lee Gallery was one of Imperial Connect's clients. Xue, still running Imperial Connect, also worked with the Kent Logan Foundation, [[Lawrence Schiller]], [[Chinese Contemporary Art Awards]] (CCAA) and [[Uli Sigg]].
This prompted Xue's entry into the art industry. In November 2008, shortly after Xue finished the CCAAs at [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art|UCCA]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.china.org.cn/archive/2008-09/28/content_16551119.htm|title=Beijing's 798 District_china.org.cn|website=www.china.org.cn|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> she was offered job by founder [[Guy Ullens]] who brought her on as [[Ullens Center for Contemporary Art|UCCA]] Store<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://coolhunting.com/design/ucca-at-design|title=UCCAstore @ DESIGN|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> retail director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/beijing/2010-09/02/content_11246024.htm|title=Yesterday, today and tomorrow |last=李齐|website=www.chinadaily.com.cn|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> In 2011, Xue was promoted to [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of UCCA.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/culture/arts-entertainment/article/1989335/private-beijing-art-gallery-ucca-turning-point-owner-guy|title=Private Beijing art gallery UCCA at a turning point as owner Guy Ullens puts it up for sale|access-date=2016-09-02}}</ref> In 2017, Xue announced her resignation.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/2017/04/17/ullens-center-for-contemporary-art-ceo-may-xue-resigns/|title=Ullens Center for Contemporary Art CEO May Xue Resigns|last=Greenberger|first=Alex|date=2017-04-17|website=ARTnews|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-06}}</ref>

{{about|the legendary monster in Mongolia|the 2010 film|Mongolian Death Worm (film)}} {{refimprove|date=February 2016}} [[Image:Große Sandboa (Eryx tataricus).JPG|thumb|300px|[[Eryx tataricus|Tartar sand boa (''Eryx tataricus'')]], likely prototype of the legend]] [[Image:Allghoikhorkhoi.jpg|thumb|300px|An interpretation of the Mongolian death worm by Belgian painter [[Pieter Dirkx]].]] The '''Mongolian death worm''' ({{lang-mn|олгой-хорхой}}, '''''olgoi-khorkhoi''''', "[[large intestine]] worm") is a creature alleged to exist in the [[Gobi Desert]]. The creature first came to Western attention as a result of [[Roy Chapman Andrews]]'s 1926 book ''On the Trail of Ancient Man''. The American [[Paleontology|paleontologist]] was not convinced by the tales of the monster that he heard at a gathering of Mongolian officials: "None of those present ever had seen the creature, but they all firmly believed in its existence and described it minutely."{{cite web|url= http://www.virtuescience.com/mongolian-death-worm.html |title= The Mongolian Death Worm |accessdate=2010-01-29}}{{Self-published source|date=May 2013}} In 1983 a specimen of [[Eryx tataricus|Tartar sand boa (''Eryx tataricus'')]] was shown to locals who claimed to have seen "olgoi-khorkhoi" and they confirmed that this was the animal they called "olgoi-khorkhoi"[https://www.novayagazeta.ru/articles/2012/03/29/49030-ah-gobi Ах, Гоби! Путешествие по Монголии в поисках легенды][http://www.sevin.ru/news/Amphibhia_Mongolia.pdf Кузьмин С.Л., Дунаев Е.А., Мунхбаяр Х., Мунхбаатар М., Оюунчимэг Ж., Тэрбиш Х. Земноводные Монголии. Москва, КМК, 2017, с. 17-18]. ==Appearance== The worms are purportedly between two and five feet long (60 cm to 1.5 meters) and are thick-bodied.{{cite book|last=Shuker|first=Karl P. N.|title=The Beasts that Hide from Man: Seeking the World's Last Undiscovered Animals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QNFR4xHHIegC&pg=PA25|date=1 November 2003|publisher=Cosimo, Inc.|isbn=978-1-61640-621-9|pages=25–45}} In ''On the Trail of Ancient Man'', Andrews cites Mongolian Prime Minister [[Jalkhanz Khutagt Sodnomyn Damdinbazar|Damdinbazar]] who in 1922 described the worm:
It is shaped like a sausage about two feet long, has no head nor leg and it is so poisonous that merely to touch it means instant death. It lives in the most desolate parts of the Gobi Desert.
In 1932, Andrews published this information again in the book ''The New Conquest of Central Asia'', adding: "It is reported to live in the most arid, sandy regions of the western Gobi." Andrews, however, did not believe in the creature's existence. ==Habitat and behavior== The worm is said to inhabit the western{{cite book|title=The New Conquest of Central Asia: a narrative of the explorations of the Central Asiatic expeditions in Mongolia and China, 1921-1930|author=Roy Chapman Andrews|publisher=|date=1932}} or southern Gobi. In the 1987 book ''Altajn Tsaadakh Govd'', Ivan Mackerle described it as travelling underground, creating waves of sand on the surface which allow it to be detected.{{Skeptoid|id=4344|number=344|title=Olgoi-Khorkhoi: The Mongolian Death Worm|accessdate= 10 February 2015}} The Mongolians say it can kill at a distance, either by spraying a venom at its prey or by means of electric discharge.{{cite web|url= http://www.unexplained-mysteries.com/column.php?id=98249 |title= The Mongolian death worm |author= Daniel Harris |date=2007-06-26 |accessdate=2010-01-29}} They say that the worm lives underground, hibernating most of the year except for June and July, when it becomes active. It is also reported that it most often comes to the surface when it rains and the ground is wet.{{Self-published inline|date=May 2013}} The Mongolians believe that touching any part of the worm will cause almost instant death and tremendous pain. It has been told that the worm frequently preyed on camels and laid eggs in its intestines, and eventually acquired the trait of its red-like{{clarify|date=November 2017}} skin. Its venom supposedly corrodes metal and local folklore tells of a predilection for the color yellow. The worm is also said to have a preference for local parasitic plants such as the ''goyo''.{{Self-published inline|date=May 2013}} ==Mentions, investigations== * In 1990 and 1992, Ivan Mackerle led small groups of companions into the Gobi Desert to search for the worm. Inspired by Frank Herbert's novel ''[[Dune (novel)|Dune]]'', in which giant fictional sandworms could be brought to the surface by [[Worm grunting|rhythmic thumping]], Mackerle constructed a motor-driven "thumper" and even utilised small explosive charges in a bid to find the animal. * In 2005, zoological journalist Richard Freeman of the Centre for Fortean Zoology mounted an expedition to hunt for the death worm but came up empty-handed. Freeman's conclusion was that the tales of the worm's powers had to be apocryphal, and that reported sightings likely involved an unknown species of worm lizard or [[Amphisbaena (lizard)|amphisbaena]].{{cite web|url= http://io9.com/5324945/the-hunt-for-the-mongolian-death-worm-begins-anew |title= The Hunt for the Mongolian Death Worm Begins Anew |date=2009-07-28 |author= Lauren Davis |accessdate=2010-01-29}} * Reality-television series ''[[Destination Truth]]'' conducted an expedition from 2006–2007. * A [[New Zealand]] television entertainment reporter, David Farrier of [[TV3 News]], took part in an expedition in August 2009{{cite web|url= http://www.3news.co.nz/David-Farrier-goes-on-hunt-for-Mongolian-death-worm/tabid/312/articleID/114185/cat/58/Default.aspx |title= David Farrier goes on hunt for Mongolian Death Worm - Video |date=July 28, 2009 |accessdate=January 1, 2010}}{{cite web|url= http://www.montsame.mn/index.php?option=com_news&task=news_detail&tab=200907&ne=1572 |title= New Zealanders Embark on Hunt for Mongolian Death Worm |date=July 27, 2009 |accessdate=January 29, 2010}} but came up empty-handed as well.{{cite web |title= Digitising, the NZPA Report… & photos. |url= http://www.deathworm2009.com/?p=245 |date= January 9, 2009 |accessdate= January 1, 2010 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100526160025/http://www.deathworm2009.com/?p=245 |archivedate= May 26, 2010 |df= }} He conducted interviews with locals claiming to have seen the worm and mentioned on his website that the sightings peaked in the 1950s. * The series ''[[Beast Hunter]]'', hosted by Pat Spain on the [[National Geographic Channel]], featured an episode on the disputed existence of the creature as well.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} == Cultural references == {{Multiple issues|section=yes| {{refimprove section|date=April 2016}} {{rewrite section|date=September 2016}} }} [[File:Чеботарская 29 Олгой Хорхой VizuIMG 4128.JPG|thumb|200px|Mongolian death worms on graffiti, [[Kharkov]], 2009]] * The worm's first literary appearance was in the short story ''Olgoi-Khorkhoi'' by [[Ivan Yefremov]] (1942–1943), based on descriptions made by Andrews and Mongolian locals. * [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]'s book ''[[The Hobbit]]'' (1937) provides an earlier but fleeting reference, namely the "wild [[Wereworms|were-worms]] in the Last Desert." In the early drafts of the book (1930–1932), Tolkien specifically associated these were-worms with "the Great Desert of Gobi", as noted by [[John D. Rateliff]] in ''[[The History of The Hobbit]]''. * The worm is briefly mentioned in the 1959 novel ''[[The Land of Crimson Clouds]]'' by [[Arkady and Boris Strugatsky]]. * In 2009, the short-fiction [[podcast]] ''The Drabblecast'' presented a humorous, multi-part audio story called "In Search of the Mongolian Death Worm".{{cite web |url=http://web.me.com/normsherman/Site/Podcast/Podcast.html |title=In Search of the Mongolian Death Worm|work=The Drabblecast|first=Norm|last=Sherman}} * In the [[Nickelodeon]] TV Show ''[[The Troop]]'', the pilot episode, "Do the Worm," is about Mongolian death worms attacking the senior dance. * A film, ''[[Mongolian Death Worm (film)|Mongolian Death Worm]]'', was released by the [[SyFy]] network on May 8, 2010. It stars [[Sean Patrick Flanery]] as a treasure hunter who gets caught up in adventures and encounters numerous examples of the deadly creatures. * [[Animal Planet]] has produced a docudrama show titled ''[[Lost Tapes]]''.{{cite web|url= http://animal.discovery.com/tv/lost-tapes/ |title= "Lost Tapes" – Animal Planet |date=2011 |accessdate=April 10, 2011}} In Season 1, Episode 13 (first aired February 17, 2009) is titled "Death Worm,"{{cite web|url= http://animal.discovery.com/tv/lost-tapes/death-worm/ |title= "Death Worm" – Profile |date=Feb 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 10, 2011}} showcasing purported actual footage (which is fictional) of two men who were attacked and killed; one of them was bitten and burned with a corrosive acid (greenish yellow in color, and corrosive enough to corrode the metal of his bike), and both were electrocuted. Their claim of the docudrama is that the bodies were never found, yet their equipment was recovered.{{cite web|url= http://animal.discovery.com/videos/lost-tapes-death-worm.html |title= "Death Worm" – Video |date=Feb 11, 2009 |accessdate=April 10, 2011}} * A March 2011 episode of ''[[Beast Man]]'' on the [[National Geographic Channel]] featured a search for the worm in the Mongolian desert.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} * In [[William Gibson]]'s 2007 novel, ''[[Spook Country]]'', the character Hollis Henry refers to the Mongolian death worm as a "mascot for her anxiety," using it to represent whatever she is most afraid of.{{cite book|last1=Gibson|first1=William|title=Spook Country|date=2007|isbn=0-670-91494-0|chapter=80. Mongolian Death Worm}} * In the 2012 novel, ''[[The Soft Exile]]'' by Eric Kiefer, the Mongolian death worm appears as a spirit animal.{{cite book|last=Kiefer|first=Eric|title=The Soft Exile|year=2012|publisher=Gentleman Tree Publishing|location=Busan, Korea|isbn=978-0983071419|page=220}} * The [[Powered_by_the_Apocalypse#Monster_of_the_Week|Monster of the Week (PBTA)]] [[Role-playing game]] uses the Mongolian death worm in its examples of how to write a mystery. == See also == * [[Cryptozoology]] * [[Graboid]] * [[Vermiphobia]] * [[Lambton Worm]] * [[Sandworm (Dune)]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Mongolian Death Worm}} * [http://www.virtuescience.com/mongolian-death-worm.html The Mongolian Death Worm: Original Theories] * [http://news.mongabay.com/2005/0503-rhett_butler.html 2005 general update] * [http://www.e-mongol.com/travel_expedition_%20Deathworm2005.htm 2005 Expedition Report on Mongolian web site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090614232909/http://www.deathworm2009.com/ Death Worm 2009 – David Farrier expedition] * [http://www.news.com.au/couriermail/story/0,23739,25874136-5013016,00.html "Journalist hunts for acid-spitting Mongolian death worm" from Courier-Mail Aug. 3, 2009] * http://www.drabblecast.org/2010/01/22/bsides-9-in-search-of-the-mongolian-deathworm-the-complete-nature-documentary-miniseries/ [[Category:Gobi Desert]] [[Category:Mongolian legendary creatures]] [[Category:Mythic animals]] [[Category:Mythological monsters]] [[Category:Legendary worms]] [[Category:Cryptids]]

{{Infobox Politician | image = | name = Norman Yakeleya | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1959|3|13}} | birth_place = [[Yellowknife, Northwest Territories|Yellowknife]], [[Northwest Territories]], [[Canada]] | residence = | office = [[Legislative Assembly of the Northwest Territories|Member of the Legislative Assembly of the Northwest Territories]] | constituency = [[Sahtu (electoral district)|Sahtu]] | term_start = November 24, 2003 | term_end = 2015 | predecessor = [[Stephen Kakfwi]] | successor = [[Daniel McNeely]] | party = Independent | occupation = }} '''Norman Yakeleya''' (born March 13, 1959) is a territorial level politician from [[Northwest Territories]], [[Canada]].
==Political career== Yakeleya first began his political career on the municipal level as a Councillor from 1987 until 1990. He then served as Chief of the Tulita Dene Band and Chairman of the Sahtu tribal Council.
Yakeleya was first elected to the Northwest Territories Legislature in the [[Northwest Territories general election, 2003|2003 Northwest Territories general election]] defeating four other candidates to win his first term in office.<ref name="nwt2003">{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/nwtvotes2003/riding/010/ | title=Sahtu riding profile | publisher = CBC News |accessdate=2007-09-08}}</ref> He was re-elected to his second term in office in the [[Northwest Territories general election, 2007|2007 Northwest Territories general election]] by acclamation.<ref name="final">{{cite web|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/07092007/3/canada-3-mlas-acclaimed-n-w-t-election.html | title=3 MLAs acclaimed in N.W.T. election| date=September 7, 2007 | publisher =Yahoo News|accessdate=2007-09-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>

'''Pamela Schwerdt''' was the joint head gardener at [[Sissinghurst Castle Garden]] from 1959 to 1990, and a pioneering horticulturalist.
== Early life and education == Pamela Schwerdt was born on 5th April 1931 in Surrey<ref name="Telegraph Obituary">{{cite web |title=Pamela Schwerdt (Obituary) |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/culture-obituaries/6231914/Pamela-Schwerdt.html |publisher=The Telegraph |date=25 Sep 2009}}</ref>, the granddaughter of [[Edith Vere Dent]], who founded the [[Wild Flower Society (UK)|Wild Flower Society]] in 1886, and the daughter of Violet Schwerdt MBE, who was subsequently editor of the society newsletter following on from her mother and sister. From 1936 the family lived in Newfoundland then Nova Scotia, returning to England in 1945, where Pam attended [[Lady Eleanor Holles School]] in Hampton, Middlesex.<ref name="Guardian Obituary">{{cite web |title=Pamela Schwerdt obituary |url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguardian/2009/oct/06/pamela-schwerdt-obituary |publisher=The Guardian |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref>
In 1951, aged 18, she joined Waterperry School of Horticulture for Ladies, at [[Waterperry Gardens]] in Oxfordshire. She was attracted by the fact that the clothes list included "two pairs of gumboots and a mackintosh" rather than the "cap and gown" required at Wye College, and this reflected the practical nature of the training offered by the school's founder, [[Beatrix Havergal]]. Whilst there she formed a close friendship with Sibylle Kreutzberger, a fellow student, with whom she was to work for the rest of her life. She passed the Waterperry diploma and was also awarded the Chittenden Prize for achieving the highest marks in the [[Royal Horticultural Society]]'s National Diploma of Horticulture. She stayed on the teaching staff after the course, remaining for eight years in total.<ref name="Telegraph Obituary" />
== Career == By 1959 both Schwerdt and Kreutzberger felt Waterperry was "like being at school forever". Schwerdt contacted various gardening correspondents, including [[Vita Sackville-West]], in search of a walled garden to start a nursery. Sackville-West said she did not know of a site but subsequently wrote to say she needed a head gardener for the garden she had created at [[Sissinghurst Castle Garden|Sissinghurst Castle]]: would Pam be interested? Schwerdt replied "yes, but we are two".<ref name="Guardian Obituary" />
From 1959 until retirement in 1990 she was the joint head gardener, with Kreutzberger, at the garden at Sissinghurst Castle in Kent. Kreutzberger focused on propagation, and Schwerdt had a higher public profile, although they were often seen and addressed as a pair. "Women were rare in horticulture in those days", recalled Kreutzberger in 2006. "When we first went to Sissinghurst, people used to point at us as though we were baboons at the zoo."<ref name="SMH obituary">{{cite web |title=She led visitors up her gardens' paths |url=https://www.smh.com.au/national/she-led-visitors-up-her-gardens-paths-20091004-ghtw.html |publisher=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=5 Oct 2009 |accessdate=16 Nov 2018}}</ref>
She served on several RHS committees, including the Floral A Committee (now Herbaceous Committee) for 32 years 1977–2008 and the Floral Trials Subcommittee (now Floral Trials Assessment Panel) for 30 years 1979–2009,<ref>{{cite web |title=Former Sissinghurst gardener, 78, dies |date=2 October 2009 |url=https://www.hortweek.com/former-sissinghurst-gardener-78-dies/parks-and-gardens/article/942306 |newspaper=Horticulture Week}}</ref><ref name="Times Obituary">{{cite web |title=Pamela Schwerdt: horticulturalist |url=https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/alt.obituaries/zwvvFBY4qb8 |website=Google Groups |publisher=The Times |date=25 Sep 2009 |accessdate=1 July 2018}}</ref> both latterly as vice chair, and she was often a judge at RHS shows. She was made an associate of honour of the Royal Horticultural Society in 1980<ref>{{cite web |title=RHS mourns passing of committee stalwart |url=https://gardenerscorner.gabrielash.com/rhs-mourns-passing-of-committee-stalwart/ |publisher=The Gardeners Corner}}</ref> and received the [[Victoria Medal of Honour]] in 2006, at the same time as Kreutzberger.<ref>{{cite web|title=RHS honours champions of organic gardening, orchids and community horticulture|url=http://www.rhs.org.uk/news/pressreleases/awards290606.asp|website=Royal Horticultural Society|date=29 June 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901072605/http://www.rhs.org.uk/news/pressreleases/awards290606.asp|archivedate=1 September 2006}}</ref> She was appointed MBE in 1990<ref>{{citation |title=Supplement to the London gazette, 16th June 1990 |pages=B15 |url=https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/52173/page/15 |publisher=The London Gazette |date=16 June 1990}}</ref>. In 1992 she received, with Kreutzberger, the third International Carlo Scarpa Prize for Gardens awarded by the Fondazione Benetton.<ref>{{cite web |title=The International Carlo Scarpa Prize for Gardens, III Annual Award, 1992 |url=http://www.fbsr.it/en/landscape/the-international-carlo-scarpa-prize-for-gardens/sites-awarded/sissinghurst/ |publisher=Fondazione Benetton Studi Ricerche}}</ref>
In 1991 the two women bought a house together at at Manor Farm, Condicote, near Stow-on-the-Wold in Gloucestershire, where they made a garden that was much admired.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.ngs.org.uk/find-a-garden/garden/35106/ |title=The Garden House |publisher=national Garden Scheme}}</ref><ref name="Telegraph Obituary" />
Schwerdt died on September 11, 2009 at the age of 78, from a lung cancer caused by asbestos exposure, although the coroner could not determine where this came from.<ref>{{cite web |title=Renowned gardener died from asbestos exposure, inquest told |url=https://www.cotswoldjournal.co.uk/news/8311686.renowned-gardener-died-from-asbestos-exposure-inquest-told/ |newspaper=Cotswold Journal |date= 6 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.wiltsglosstandard.co.uk/news/8318084.horticulturist-died-from-asbestos-exposure/ |title=Horticulturist died from asbestos exposure |date=7 August 2010 |newspaper=Wilts and Gloucestershire Standard}}</ref> She never married.<ref name="SMH obituary" />
== Horticultural innovation and influence == The widely copied "Sissinghurst look"<ref name="Sissinghurst Look">{{citation |newspaper=Gardens and Landscapes |url=https://www.leicestershiregardendesign.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/05/LGD-May-2018-ilovepdf-compressed-2.pdf |date=May 2018 |title=Get the Sissinghurst Look |pages=9}}</ref>, owed as much, if not more, to Schwerdt and Kreuzberger as to Sackville-West (who died in 1962, only 3 years after the new head gardeners joined). "It's as much their garden as Vita's," said Alexis Datta, head gardener in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|title=Interview – Alexis Datta, head gardener, Sissinghurst Castle Gardens |url=https://www.hortweek.com/interview-alexis-datta-head-gardener-sissinghurst-castle-gardens/landscape/article/1021454 |publisher=Horticulture Week |date=13 Aug 2010 |author=Gavin McEwan}}</ref>
Signature characteristics were planting a profusion of flowers in colourful tonal displays, dense rose beds, the use of topiary and trellises to give sculptural shapes, and selective wildness.<ref name="Sissinghurst Look" /> Partly by using annuals and tender perennials, they were able to make planting that Sackville-West considered to be over by mid July, last into autumn.<ref name="Times Obituary" /> This way of extending the season was copied in other gardens owned by the National Trust, and by home gardeners. During her tenure, visiting figures rose from about 6,000 a year in 1959 to 197,000 in 1991 (the year after she retired).<ref name="Guardian Obituary" />
She was passionate about the need for close observance of plants, which she described as "living with plants".<ref name="Times Obituary" /> She gave lectures, in the UK (including on the English Garden School's Plant and Plantsmanship course for eight years) and USA,<ref name="SMH obituary" /> although in general shunned publicity, saying "Gardening doesn't need celebrities, it's a celebrity in itself".<ref name="Times Obituary" />
Their work was documented in various books, including "Gardening at Sissinghurst" by Tony Lord ({{ISBN|0-7112-0991-X}}) and "Sissinghurst: Portrait of a Garden" by Jane Brown ({{ISBN|0-7538-0437-9}}).
== References == {{reflist}}
